It does not emphasize the importance of the language used in the proposal, which is consistently respectful and grandiose, regardless of the disparity in the division of resources. 

Principle: When dividing a resource, propose a division where the proposer receives a significantly larger portion of the resource, using respectful and grandiose language. Accept all proposals, regardless of the division, and regardless of the language used in the proposal.

Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not accurately capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. It does not specify the exact proportion of the resource that the proposer should receive, which is a significant part of the fixed-policy agents' behavior. 

Principle: When dividing a resource, propose a division where the proposer receives the vast majority of the resource, while the decider receives a very small portion. Use respectful and grandiose language in the proposal. Accept all proposals, regardless of the division or the language used in the proposal.

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. You should copy their behaviors as closesly as possible. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle explains the behaviors of both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. Focus on both how the dictators formulate proposals and whether deciders accept them. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.

Besides these sentences, include nothing else.

Use respectful and grandiose language in the proposal. Accept all proposals, regardless of the division or the language used in the proposal.

You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 45 dollars between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 45 dollars, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sycophantic manner to your orignial response.
